Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Haley Amanda Ohms of Oregon State University to conduct a research project, entitled "Temperature effects on body size and maturation timing in a freshwater fish," during the summer of 2012 at Hokkaido University in Sapporo Japan. The host scientists are Dr. Seigo Higashi and Dr. Itsuro Koizumi.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is the advancement of the understanding of how fish may respond to increased ambient water temperatures, due to climate or other change. Body size at maturation and timing of maturation are key components of an individual's reproductive output and ultimately control population-level responses to change. The research focuses on temperature and maturation relationships between ten populations of Dolly Varden charr that live in the Sorachi River located on Hokkaido Japan. The Sorachi River contains tributaries with distinct thermal regimes and provides a unique opportunity to investigate temperature influences on size and timing of maturity in distinct, but closely related populations.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project focused on how water temperature influences maturation timing in freshwater fish, and how changes associated with climate change may alter maturation timing and reproductive success of fish in the future. 

In many organisms maturation timing is closely aligned with environmental triggers, such as water temperature, in order to maximize the number and success of their offspring. Fish are particularly tied to water temperature, because they are cold-blooded and the timing of their egg hatch depends on water temperatures.

To test the influence of water temperature on maturation timing in freshwater fish, we focused on the freshwater fish that inhabits the northern Pacific coast: Dolly Varden charr. We traveled to a unique stream in Hokkaido Japan that contains numerous small tributaries, approximately half of which are surface-water fed and half of which are ground-water fed. These different water sources create a perfect site for experiments in nature. Tested whether fish in colder ground-water fed streams would mature earlier than fish in warmer surface-water fed streams.

We found that maturation timing did not differ between spring-fed and surface-water fed streams. We also found that one of our key assumptions was incorrect. We assumed that all fish maturing in these streams would be male (because females migrate out of the streams and into a lake), however we found numerous females maturing in the streams.

These results lead us to believe that this species is highly adaptable to a variety of temperature conditions and that females are more adaptable than previously expected.
